title: 'I've got 25 tenants chasing every property' - buy-to-let tycoon Fergus Wilson
text:
59.03 -3.48 
Controversial landlord warns of housing 'disaster' with multiple families forced to share a single property, or live in prefab homes 'like after the war' 
Controversial landlord couple Fergus and Judith Wilson say demand from prospective tenants is at a record high. 
Despite profiting hugely from a chronic shortage of housing, Mr Wilson now condemns the Government for its failure to build enough homes - and warns that house-sharing by families could become the norm in some areas, as in the postwar period. 
"My parents lived in a shared house and had two rooms for two adults and three children," he said. "In the South East we are moving back to those days." 
His parents moved into a council house in 1952, he said, following a huge national programme of housebuilding. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) comes as Mr and Mrs Wilson are offloading hundreds of properties from their portfolio , which at one time comprised 1,000 properties variously valued at between £200m and £250m. 
The properties are almost all two-bed and three-bed homes in the Kent towns of Ashford (AMEX: AINC - news ) , Maidstone and Folkestone. 
Mr Wilson, in his late 60s, told The Telegraph that in the past few days agents from these areas had reported enormous demand, including "25 prospective tenants seeking a two-bed house". 
"The agent asked if he could take some of my houses which are currently up for sale and make them available for desperate tenants," Mr Wilson said. 
"My answer was no, they are for desperate owner-occupiers." 
He said he had sold three properties to owner-occupiers in the past week. 
• Death of buy-to-let: landlords wake up to Osborne's 150pc tax 
The Wilsons clearly stand to gain by talking up the demand for both rental property and property for owner-occupiers. They are selling to both categories of buyer. 
Mr Wilson said that, when selling to other investors, he has been selling "in bulk at a minimum of 10 properties, with tenants in situ". 
But he said that where tenancies had ended he sold homes on an individual basis to owner-occupiers, where demand for stock is extremely high . 
"There is an extreme shortage of vacant houses for estate agents to sell and the stock is depleted to the levels of 10 years ago," he said. 
= New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) buy-to-let tax 'will push up rents' = 
Like many other landlords the Wilsons have criticised George Osborne's new tax on buy-to-let, which will make it impossible for landlords to deduct mortgage interest costs from their taxable profits. 
Some will have to pay tax on zero income or even on net losses as a result of the change. 
There is a growing consensus that the effect will be to push up rents. The tax change takes full effect only from 2020. 
"We now have the Conservative government seeking to change the rules retrospectively," Mr Wilson said. "Investors enter with their eyes open and expect whatever tax arrangements on entry to prevail until exit. 
"There are now Investors looking towards 2020 saying they would not have entered this form of Investment had they been aware at the time of the proposed tax changes. 
"The Government needs to think this out. It needs private landlords because it does not wish to fund houses for the social sector." 
He pointed out that foreign buyers, cash buyers and institutional buyers - such as pension funds and insurance companies - were not affected by Mr Osborne's new tax. 
But he said many landlords who did face the tax would respond by forcing higher rents on tenants. The shortage of properties will mean tenants have little choice. 
This view has been echoed by others. The Council of Mortgage Lenders, representing banks that lend to landlords, warned that one consequence of the tax would be higher rents . Some landlords might simply sell up and further reduce the supply of rented accommodation, it added. 
John Goodall, chief executive of Landbay, a funding platform for landlords, said: "It's basic economics. You've got rising demand for rented property and a limited supply. If you add a new tax into that equation, the tax will simply get passed on to the tenants." 
At Labour's conference in Brighton, shadow housing minister John Healey announced a review into home ownershp to be overseen by Peter Redfern, chief executive of housebuilder Taylor Wimpey (LSE: TW.L - news ) . 
The backdrop is a wider concern that the growth of buy-to-let as a preferred source of income and capital growth for many investors risks destabilising the economy .
